Award.AwardTitle: Upstate New York Number Theory Conference
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in four meetings in a series of annual conferences in number theory held in Upstate New York; the first conference will take place in Ithaca from April 10 to April 12 in 2015, the second conference in Rochester in 2016, the third conference in Binghamton in 2017, and the fourth conference in Buffalo in 2018. The investigators represent four different institutions: Binghamton University, Cornell University, SUNY-Buffalo, and the University of Rochester. The conference series seeks to have a broader impact in a number of ways. It will help graduate students and post-docs by exposing them to work of leading experts, by allowing them to communicate their own research and interests, and by giving them the chance to interact with experts, among themselves and with young people from nearby places. It will also allow specialists to disseminate their ideas to a larger audience.

At the level of faculty research, the conference series will stimulate collaborations among several specialists in the region, while at the same time strengthening ties between researchers in Upstate New York and those near Boston, New York City, Montreal, Philadelphia, Princeton, and Toronto. The meetings will catalyze the region's research in number theory and will enrich the opportunities for education and professional development available to junior researchers in the region. The first conference will be centered on the themes of arithmetic geometry over finite fields and new directions in automorphic forms. More information about the conference series can be found at http://www.math.cornell.edu/~upstatenumber/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Upstate New York Number Theory conference is an annual conference held in the Spring that rotates between institutions in Upstate New York. The 5th conference was held on April 10-12, 2015 at Cornell University. The 6th conference was held on April 30-May 1, 2016 at Rochester University. The 7th conference was held on May 6-7, 2017 at Binghamton University. The 8th conference was held on April 28-29, 2018 at the University of Buffalo, in conjunction with Daemen College.

A primary goal of these conferences was to bring together the specialists from the various branches of number theory in the Upstate New York region and surrounding areas and to expose the younger researchers to new and old problems in the field. It provided opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in mathematics. 

In total there were delivered 27 one-hour plenary talks and 112 contributing talks. Participants and speakers expressed their interest in coming back to the subsequent conferences and to other number theory activities such as local seminars.

A large proportion of the conference participants were graduate students and postdocs.  It has allowed them to be exposed to the work and to communicate their own research with leading experts and other young researchers from nearby places.
